nodes.bodyText:
Just a thought : A filter applies per message while a comparator is something which needs to be set only once for entire set of messages.
How would it look like if we then pass the comparator to IterableInboxFragment and not have interface approach there? may be like this.setComparator(comparator)?
Beginning with API 24, and our minimum API level is 15...
Just curious. Not a comment. This seems to be too verbose. Does Android support lambda expressions.
It does support lambda expressions if using java > 8.0 or Kotlin.

It does or it does not, depending on the version of the build tools. Android runtime is still considered Java 6, so you have to use a desugaring compiler to transform Java 8 lambdas into Java 6 constructs. It'd be an easy 'yes' if this were a mobile app, but for a library I'm not exactly sure if we can use lambdas safely.
Not sure, but will there be scenario where adaptor values need to be changed without destroying it?
There shouldn't be. Since the Fragment can be destroyed and created again with just arguments, we should limit what can be modified on the Adapter or the Fragment I think..
I’m actually thinking about making these setters protected so they can only be called from a subclass..
Now I second on moving to Kotlin 😁
message2 compareTo message1 can help us get rid of the minus(-) prefix
This is intentional. I never remember whether comparator should compare o1 with o2 or vice versa, but the negative sign informs that we’re reversing the order.
